abstracts.cdata!:
The economic recovery program launches a
            series of macroeconomic, structural and social policies to
            accompany the decision of the African member countries of
            the Franc Zone to devalue their currency, the CFA franc,
            effective January 12, 1994. The Economic Recovery Credit
            Project will support the post-devluation reform program as
            outlined in the Government's Statement of Economic and
            Social Policy whose main objectives are to restore order to
            public finances and to lay the basis for growth and the
            alleviation of poverty. More particularly, it will support
            the measures aimed at minimizing the negative social impact
            of the devaluation in the short term. The Chadian Government
            has already taken a series of key macroeconomic and
            structural measures to regain and consolidate
            competitiveness, and to stabilize its public finances. The
            Economic Recovery Credit (ERC) is designed to support the
            implementation of these measures in 1994. The major measures
            are: (i) the devaluation of the CFA Franc from 50 CFAF to
            100 CFAF/1 FF; (ii) prudent demand management policies to
            reduce absorption by the public sector and limit wage
            increases; (iii) budget reform and strengthening of tax
            collection; (iv) increase in the producer price of cotton
            for the 1994/95 crop by 50; (v) a program of social measures
            to attenuate the effects of the devaluation on vulnerable
            groups; and (vi) protection of social sector expenditures.
